Review visit for chest pain, medication adjustment and lifestyle counselling.
Review visit for chest pain, medication adjustment and lifestyle counselling.
Diagnosis: Stable angina with underlying dyslipidemia and sedentary lifestyle.
Tests: ECG (resting), 2D Echo, Fasting lipid profile, Fasting blood sugar, TMT (after cardiology clearance)
Medicines:
Tab. Ecosprin AV 75/20 mg | 1-0-0 | After dinner | 90 days
Tab. Metoprolol 25 mg | 0-0-1 | Night | 30 days
S.L. Sorbitrate 5 mg | SOS | Max 3 tablets per day
Tab. Vitamin D3 60k | 1 tab weekly | 6 weeks
Precautions: Avoid heavy meals late at night, restrict oily and fried foods, 30 minutes brisk walking on 5 days per week after 2 weeks if symptom-free, stop smoking completely, limit tea/coffee to 2 cups/day.
Advice / Notes: Explained difference between cardiac and muscular chest pain. Reviewed previous ECG and current vitals – stable. Patient counselled on avoiding sudden exertion; asked to maintain a symptom diary. Emergency red flags explained: chest pain at rest, severe sweating, radiation to jaw/left arm.

Reason: Follow-up for migraine control and review of headache diary.
Follow-up for recent viral fever, appetite and activity check.
Diagnosis: Acute viral upper respiratory infection with low-grade fever.
Tests: None immediately required; consider CBC and CRP if fever persists beyond 5 days.
Medicines:
Syp. Paracetamol 250 mg/5ml | 10 ml SOS | Every 6 hours for fever > 100°F
Syp. Cetirizine 5 mg/5ml | 5 ml at night | 5 days
Saline nasal drops | 2 drops each nostril | 4–5 times/day
Precautions: Ensure adequate oral fluids (ORS, soups, coconut water), light, easily digestible home food, avoid forced feeding. Monitor temperature every 4–6 hours and watch for breathing difficulty or poor feeding.
Advice / Notes: Child active and playful, hydration status good. No signs of serious bacterial infection. Explained fever as a natural defence mechanism. Parents advised not to overuse antibiotics.

Reason: Follow-up for knee osteoarthritis and exercise compliance.
Diagnosis: Early osteoarthritis of knee with quadriceps muscle weakness.
Tests: X-ray both knees (standing), Serum Vitamin D3, Serum Calcium.
Medicines:
Tab. Aceclofenac 100 mg + Paracetamol 325 mg | 1-0-1 | After food | 5 days
Tab. Calcium + Vitamin D3 | 1-0-0 | 3 months
Topical Diclofenac gel | Apply thin layer | 2–3 times/day on knee joint
Precautions: Avoid squatting, sitting cross-legged, climbing stairs repeatedly. Use Western toilet, use handrails while using stairs. Target weight loss of 4–5 kg over next 3 months.
Advice / Notes: Explained degenerative nature of osteoarthritis and importance of weight reduction. Demonstrated quadriceps strengthening and hamstring stretching exercises in detail. Discussed role of physiotherapy and footwear modification.

Reason: Review of acne response to topical regimen and sunscreen use.
Follow-up for migraine control and review of headache diary.
Review of acne response to topical regimen and sunscreen use.
Diagnosis: Moderate inflammatory acne vulgaris with early post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.
Tests: No routine tests required at this stage; consider hormonal workup if resistant.
Medicines:
Clindamycin + Nicotinamide gel | Apply thin layer over active acne | Morning | 8 weeks
Adapalene 0.1% gel | Pea-sized amount over entire face | Night | 8–12 weeks
Non-comedogenic moisturizer | Twice daily as needed
Gel-based sunscreen SPF 30+ | Apply every 3–4 hours during day
Precautions: Avoid heavy, oily cosmetics and home remedies like lemon or toothpaste on skin. Use gentle cleanser twice a day, avoid over-washing. Maintain regular sleep, reduce high-glycemic foods and sugary drinks.
Advice / Notes: Explained that acne treatment requires 8–12 weeks for visible improvement. Advised patient not to squeeze/pick lesions to avoid scarring. Discussed skincare routine suitable for oily, acne-prone skin.

Reason: Follow-up for migraine control and review of headache diary.
Diagnosis: Chronic migraine without aura, likely triggered by irregular sleep and screen exposure.
Tests: MRI brain (plain), Serum Vitamin D3, CBC, Thyroid profile (TSH, Free T4)
Medicines:
Tab. Propranolol 20 mg | 1-0-1 | After food | 30 days
Tab. Naproxen 500 mg | SOS for severe headache | Max 2/day
Tab. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) 100 mg | 1-0-0 | 60 days
Precautions: Maintain fixed sleep and wake-up times, avoid skipping meals, limit continuous screen time to max 30–40 minutes at a stretch, stay hydrated (2.5–3 L water/day), avoid loud music and bright flashing lights.
Advice / Notes: Explained migraine nature, common triggers and importance of lifestyle modification. Asked patient to maintain a headache diary (intensity, duration, triggers, response to meds). Discussed stress management techniques and sleep hygiene.

Reason: Follow-up for recent viral fever, appetite and activity check.
Review of acne response to topical regimen and sunscreen use.
Diagnosis: Moderate inflammatory acne vulgaris with early post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.
Tests: No routine tests required at this stage; consider hormonal workup if resistant.
Medicines:
Clindamycin + Nicotinamide gel | Apply thin layer over active acne | Morning | 8 weeks
Adapalene 0.1% gel | Pea-sized amount over entire face | Night | 8–12 weeks
Non-comedogenic moisturizer | Twice daily as needed
Gel-based sunscreen SPF 30+ | Apply every 3–4 hours during day
Precautions: Avoid heavy, oily cosmetics and home remedies like lemon or toothpaste on skin. Use gentle cleanser twice a day, avoid over-washing. Maintain regular sleep, reduce high-glycemic foods and sugary drinks.
Advice / Notes: Explained that acne treatment requires 8–12 weeks for visible improvement. Advised patient not to squeeze/pick lesions to avoid scarring. Discussed skincare routine suitable for oily, acne-prone skin.

Reason: Review visit for chest pain, medication adjustment and lifestyle counselling.
Diagnosis: Stable angina with underlying dyslipidemia and sedentary lifestyle.
Tests: ECG (resting), 2D Echo, Fasting lipid profile, Fasting blood sugar, TMT (after cardiology clearance)
Medicines:
Tab. Ecosprin AV 75/20 mg | 1-0-0 | After dinner | 90 days
Tab. Metoprolol 25 mg | 0-0-1 | Night | 30 days
S.L. Sorbitrate 5 mg | SOS | Max 3 tablets per day
Tab. Vitamin D3 60k | 1 tab weekly | 6 weeks
Precautions: Avoid heavy meals late at night, restrict oily and fried foods, 30 minutes brisk walking on 5 days per week after 2 weeks if symptom-free, stop smoking completely, limit tea/coffee to 2 cups/day.
Advice / Notes: Explained difference between cardiac and muscular chest pain. Reviewed previous ECG and current vitals – stable. Patient counselled on avoiding sudden exertion; asked to maintain a symptom diary. Emergency red flags explained: chest pain at rest, severe sweating, radiation to jaw/left arm.

Reason: Follow-up for knee osteoarthritis and exercise compliance.
Diagnosis: Early osteoarthritis of knee with quadriceps muscle weakness.
Tests: X-ray both knees (standing), Serum Vitamin D3, Serum Calcium.
Medicines:
Tab. Aceclofenac 100 mg + Paracetamol 325 mg | 1-0-1 | After food | 5 days
Tab. Calcium + Vitamin D3 | 1-0-0 | 3 months
Topical Diclofenac gel | Apply thin layer | 2–3 times/day on knee joint
Precautions: Avoid squatting, sitting cross-legged, climbing stairs repeatedly. Use Western toilet, use handrails while using stairs. Target weight loss of 4–5 kg over next 3 months.
Advice / Notes: Explained degenerative nature of osteoarthritis and importance of weight reduction. Demonstrated quadriceps strengthening and hamstring stretching exercises in detail. Discussed role of physiotherapy and footwear modification.

Reason: Follow-up for recent viral fever, appetite and activity check.
Diagnosis: Acute viral upper respiratory infection with low-grade fever.
Tests: None immediately required; consider CBC and CRP if fever persists beyond 5 days.
Medicines:
Syp. Paracetamol 250 mg/5ml | 10 ml SOS | Every 6 hours for fever > 100°F
Syp. Cetirizine 5 mg/5ml | 5 ml at night | 5 days
Saline nasal drops | 2 drops each nostril | 4–5 times/day
Precautions: Ensure adequate oral fluids (ORS, soups, coconut water), light, easily digestible home food, avoid forced feeding. Monitor temperature every 4–6 hours and watch for breathing difficulty or poor feeding.
Advice / Notes: Child active and playful, hydration status good. No signs of serious bacterial infection. Explained fever as a natural defence mechanism. Parents advised not to overuse antibiotics.

Reason: Follow-up for migraine control and review of headache diary.
Diagnosis: Chronic migraine without aura, likely triggered by irregular sleep and screen exposure.
Tests: MRI brain (plain), Serum Vitamin D3, CBC, Thyroid profile (TSH, Free T4)
Medicines:
Tab. Propranolol 20 mg | 1-0-1 | After food | 30 days
Tab. Naproxen 500 mg | SOS for severe headache | Max 2/day
Tab. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) 100 mg | 1-0-0 | 60 days
Precautions: Maintain fixed sleep and wake-up times, avoid skipping meals, limit continuous screen time to max 30–40 minutes at a stretch, stay hydrated (2.5–3 L water/day), avoid loud music and bright flashing lights.
